Posts.Content: Hi Sunflower my journey pretty much the same as yours and for that I am eternally grateful and humble. I finished rads about 8 weeks ago. i am struggling with the focusing too.  I think it’s because all priorities have changed and a lot of things  that I thought were important no longer matter.  Our bodies and brains have had a lot to deal with and it’s going to take time.  A lot of things don’t mean a jot to me and I can get frustrated wondering why they are important to someone else - but I am teaching myself tolerance Good luck with the rads, and the Tamoxifen is fine too hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: Restless and feeling guilty about it

Posts.Content: Glad I made you laugh   i can totally understand your feelings, it takes a lot of adjusting and sometimes you just need some space - it’s hard to do that with a house full. But you will get there in the end x radiotherapy was fine too, nothing like I had imagined in my head.  You will be great x
Posts.Title: Restless and feeling guilty about it

Posts.Content: They definitely remove my filter, but you will be fine.   You will never be never alone on here, it is an absolute godsend of support and info. I am an absolute ogre if I don’t split my tablets, (I like you very good at biting my tongue or counting to 10) i have half in the morning and half in the evening. Been on them since March. I My 15 year old daughter told me if I accidentally took two I would be Satan.   I started with one whole tablets, was dark, depressed, lethargic and angry  and just not nice.  Started splitting after asking GP and all is good, honestly it is.  That good that I decided my body had built up enough tolerance I could go back to a whole one - big mistake within four days I was speaking to no one and no one was speaking to me. My mums central heating broke in the colder weather while I was taking the whole ones - I’m like that’s nothing - put on a blooming cardi woman! I’m embarrassed about that now. All good now though, xx
Posts.Title: Restless and feeling guilty about it

Posts.Content: Me too Lisa,  I turn up at work every day but really have no interest or focus on what is going on.  I get up and walk round the building every half an hour - struggle to sit still. I used to love this job. Five months on the tamoxifen for me. i was signed off by the hospital yesterday and am going on my hols next week.  I am hoping that when I return I will have closed another door on the way back to normality, and my focus will return. ange xx
Posts.Title: Restless and feeling guilty about it

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Just copied this from the oncotype page.   The results take a couple of weeks to come back, but for those that are able to avoid chemo well worth the wait xx If you have recently been diagnosed with early-stage oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) invasive breast cancer, you will discuss your treatment options with your doctor*. Choosing the optimal treatment for your breast cancer is important and you need to weigh the risks and benefits of chemotherapy with your doctor in order to make a decision that is right for you. Applying Genomics to Cancer A genomic test, such as the Oncotype DX test for invasive breast cancer, looks at groups of genes and how active they are. This activity can influence how a cancer is likely to grow and respond to treatment. Unlike a breast cancer genetic test, the Oncotype DX breast cancer test does not provide information about a person’s inherited genetic make-up; instead it looks at genes in a patient’s breast tumour to understand how these genes interact and influence the tumour’s behaviour. Because every woman’s tumor is unique, understanding the biology of your specific tumor will help you and your doctor make more confident decisions about your care. Find out if you’re eligible for the test.  About the Test To date, the Oncotype breast cancer test has been ordered in over 850,000 patients. The Oncotype DX test can thus help you and your doctor to make a more informed and personalised decision about whether to treat with chemotherapy or not, based on further information that is specific to the biology of your cancer. The Oncotype DX test has been available in the UK and Ireland since the end of 2007, with usage in both the NHS and private sectors growing
Posts.Title: I e been asked today what my Oncotype DX Test result was by a friend...

Posts.Content: Hi @gablegirl Good luck with the onco appointment tomorrow.  It seems at every twist and turn there's another curve ball to be dealt with.  Fab news with the letrizole though. I have been moisturising three times a day and upped my water intake too, I have read this is good as well. Best wishes and hopeful that your rads will start next week. Ange xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Thank you - still hoping to join Team April, but will probs have to dip my toes in Team May too. Loving the humour, positivity and sarcasm shown by everyone, so will still be checking in to see you progress over the next week. Hugs Ange Xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi all Hope to be starting rads in the next two weeks. I have had my planning meeting and am just waiting for a start date. It seems a very long time since the op on 5th Feb. I've started drinking more water and am moisturising like crazy.  Any other hints or tips will be great. Thanks Ange X
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Ladies Dohayogi, Mumof3plusoh, Gablegirl It seems we have all suffered with the waiting over the past couple of months, it's so the hardest time- because what you don't know your brain makes up. Has anyone started on the tamoxifen/letrizol - how are you finding it? I'm on day 11 of the tamoxifen, no problems so far - fingers tightly crossed. I have been moisturising like crazy neck, armpit etc has anyone been advised to use a particular cream.  I read somewhere on here that Aveeno was good so that's what I have, not sure whether to ask my GP for the R1 and R2 creams as they seem to have good reviews. Still having the odd wobble too, although less so than at the start. But am still wondering whether my new normal is going to be made up of a lot more wobbles even as I move forward. Dohayogi you must have amazing friends to make you something so beautiful and thoughtful. We will march (possibly amble) through this next step together, we've all been on a really long journey but there is an end in sight (nearly). Hugs and best wishes Ange xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Wishing all you lovelies a good week with the zaps. Unfortunately I have found out I won't start mine until next week, after speaking to BC nurse.  9 weeks post op today, although I think I am better at waiting now (after all the practice). Hugs Ange xxx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Congratulations Ginacarla Woo woo, you’ve got this covered. I hope you have a sense of relief, and feel safe in the knowledge that you will continue to be monitored. I hope with time, that this journey for all of us is stored away safely and not the encompassing brain buster which is our first and last thought every day. I wish you a long, healthy and happy life. Hugs Ange x
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Morning all First zap for me this afternoon.  After all this wait I am now a bit apprehensive, but on the the other side, so ready to start this so that i can wrap it all up and put it in a box called ‘the past’. Jill good luck with your meeting and appointments, fingers crossed for you.  Re the deodorant I am using simple roll on too.  Not sure if my senses are hyper-vigilant but I am more aware of any odours on my op side. Jo Jo & Twinkle hope the soreness doesn’t last too long. Good luck with the traffic Sam. Enjoy the sunshine Ange x
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Gablegirl The waiting is so hard, my op was 5th Feb and I haven't got a start date yet.  When I had the Onc appointment on the 23rd they said a couple of weeks so I am hoping for the week starting the 9th April.   Best wishes and here's hoping for start dates for all those waiting xx

Posts.Content: Hi Karebear I am no 7/20 for rads and just over 5 weeks on the Tamoxifen.   Both are going ok so far. No chemo for me due to Onco score, which I am more than grateful for. How are things going for you? Ange x
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Great News Jackie On both the start date and R1 and R2 cream. You must be able to see the finish line! The boosts are a weird one, I am having 15 + 5. For Grade 2 - originally Grade 3 (they re-examined). I have Drs at 12 to see if I can get the creams, so fingers crossed. Still waiting for a start date. Hope all goes well for you. Ange xxx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Glad to be taking this next step with you, and not alone.  As with this whole journey I am apprehensive but keen to get started. 15 + 5 boosters Have you had any specific instructions ahead of your first session?  Good luck and here's wishing that this goes quickly, with only slightly pink boobs xx Ange x
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Rads all going to plan zap 4 of 20 today, all ok. Had a couple of teary days not sure if it’s the rads, tamoxifen or just everything. But feeling a bit brighter today thank goodness. Jill you seem to have it all going on, I hope the rads are going well.  The experts have your best interests at heart, so hopefully that will help when making the decision. I am 2% under 50 too! Jan good luck with your first zaps tomorrow, I still haven’t opened my eyes so can’t tell you what goes on Wishing you all a peaceful and positive week. Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Jill (sorry can’t tag on iPad) Sorry to hear about your Dad x all the experience from this year is really shouting at us all ‘live life, enjoy, find happiness’ because we just don’t know what’s around the next corner.  I have a holiday booked for August with the family and a trip to watch the F1 in Singapore in September for my 50th birthday treat.  I have started saying yes and no a lot more putting myself first. No chemo for me fortunately, my onc score was 19.  I had done a lot of research prior and had decided that for me anything below 25 and I would have opted out, each of us have to make a decision that we can live with.  Fortunately the decision was taken out of my hands as the Oncologist said no chemo. The Tamoxfen is honestly fine, day 32 (I am taking at 18:30) and I have not noticed too much difference, night sweats (but I was going to get them at some point anyway).  In fact I was keen to start taking them ASAP because I kept thinking that the conditions of my body were susceptible to growing BC and anything I could do to alter these levels would help prevent another incident. There has been an item on our breakfast Tv news this morning about high % of women opting out of Tamoxifen,  and how it is astonishing medics around the world, that something that assists in preventing an event (in those high risk) is being refused for fear of side effects. Rads are all fine drinking an extra two litres and moisturising often. I seem to have missed the tiredness so far, although I know it is coming. Big hugs and best wishes to all on this journey. Ange x
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Afternoon everyone and a Great big Happy Birthday Pam Happy to see that things are going well for you ladies that have started the zaps. Fingers crossed for a low Onco for you Jill,  Ange xx

Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Alison Well done for finishing your treatment.  Relief mixed in with a whole lot of other emotions so it sounds. Your post is really interesting.  I think we all are still in shock when we are put on this conveyor of treatment, worrying about results, procedures, and waiting for the next step, trying to heal and being strong for those around us. And then someone shakes your hand, says there you go you’re back to normal now. I can feel my brain having a mini panic just thinking about normal. Lovely to hear you have a BC nurse that understands all this. Bit jealous really, I don’t have a tunic - just have to whip my top off.   I hope you have a lovely rest, and wish you a fabulous, long and happy life xxx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Well done Sam, glad you got to ring that bell.  Makes me fill up just thinking about the journeys we’ve all been on.  Wishing you the very best and brightest future. I am counting down the days, 7 done and all fine so far.  I have a day off tomorrow while the machine is serviced.  Jan, sorry to hear about the swelling, hopefully they will be able to work around it, please let us know how you get on. Jill hope you have a lovely weekend, and glad to hear the zaps are going well. Bit emotional this morning reading your posts and realising how bloody strong and amazing you all are. Sending love and peacefulness and wine (if only) Ange xxx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Congratulations on finishing treatment Gablegirl Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy I know exactly how you feel.  It's like the pause button has been pressed and everything is going on around you,  people seem to be getting on with their lives around you and with me I found it most difficult when people had little gripes about the everyday things - I would be thinking I wish all I had to worry about was the boiler not working etc Everyone will tell you it's the waiting that's the worse, and once things start moving its easier. I had the same op 6 weeks ago and am waiting to see the oncologist for my treatment plan.   Big hug Ange
Posts.Title: Test Results

Posts.Content: Sorry, I forgot to say - my daughter is 14  I told her I had a lump that needed to be removed and post op I told her what it was.  It was easier for me to tell her I had it, rather than I have it. she has told me since she is glad that I told her once it had been removed as she would have been more worried. Shebknows that the treatment I will be having is preventative. She is a little older than yours tho.  I told my closest friends and family as I knew I would need their support xx.

Posts.Content: Morning Coco I found this, study on intermediate onco scores, www.nature.com/.../s41523-017-0034-6 Hopefully it will ease your mind a little. Ange xxx

Posts.Title: ER positive clear nodes grade 3 and waiting on oncotype results.....

Posts.Content: Hi Coco That intermediate area seems to be no mans land and probably the most difficult. But my thoughts are we must be borderline for them to even to do the Oncotype.  I had a diagram the other day, which showed inconclusive evidence for chemo in the intermediate group.   I think that I am going to be in the intermediate so have been looking at research. I am grade 3, PR8+ER8+ Her2 negative. Best wishes Ange xx
Posts.Title: ER positive clear nodes grade 3 and waiting on oncotype results.....

Posts.Content: You are very welcome Coco We are all in this together and need each other xx. No one can understand the highs and lows like we can, the strange thoughts and emotions would send us round the bend without people to share with. Love and hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: ER positive clear nodes grade 3 and waiting on oncotype results.....

Posts.Content: You are very welcome Coco We are all in this together and need each other xx. No one can understand the highs and lows like we can, the strange thoughts and emotions would send us round the bend without people to share with. Love and hugs Ange xx

Posts.Content: Hi Coco That intermediate area seems to be no mans land and probably the most difficult. But my thoughts are we must be borderline for them to even to do the Oncotype.  I had a diagram the other day, which showed inconclusive evidence for chemo in the intermediate group.   I think that I am going to be in the intermediate so have been looking at research. Posts.Title: ER positive clear nodes grade 3 and waiting on oncotype results.....

Posts.Content: Hi Restory I was diagnosed in Jan this year. I have a daughter who is 14, and we are very close too.  I made a decision to not tell her until after the lumpectomy, and then I could tell her I HAD breast cancer rather than I have.  I told her the day I came hope after the op, and explained the rest of the treatment was preventative.  She coped really well with this and a week later told me she was ver happy that I told her this way. Sods Law but she is  taking triple science and learning about radiotherapy - just as I started mine, that led to some interesting discussions - ‘why are they treating you for something that has gone’ ‘do you know radiotherapy does this’ Just glad she is still talking about it and not keeping it to herself. I also phoned and spoke to her year head and explained the situation and the need for support. The school have been brilliant, if she feels tearful (and there have been a couple of days)  she sits in with the year head in whichever lesson he is taking.   Just as it is difficult for us to find someone who understands, it is the same for them.  Hugs Ange x
Posts.Title: mum of only child fear

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady What a coincidence I have been to Hatton Locks a few times since diagnosis. Nice fresh air, lovely cake and coffee in the cafe.  I don't live too far from there. Lovely photos. Ange x
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady  Your whole post just made me smile and chuckle.   I didn't realise when I chose the name, people may see this as a reflection of how I felt about my my diagnosis as it sounds quite angry (I usually use sortitoutkids - as it seemed to be my mantra until they reached their teens).  Should have chosen something lovely like cubansunshine It's been muddy and wet every time we have been, lots of lovely dogs and people in wellies,  Next time xxxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Concepta I had the same idea for my hospital.  I asked the Macmillan nurse why there wasnt one already.  She explained that not everyone has an end to their treatment.  That as cancer treatment has advanced there are people who will be receiving treatment for many years, therefore not getting the chance to ring the bell. Just something to consider when deciding where the bell is located. Ange xxxx
Posts.Title: A Bell To Ring

Posts.Content: Hi all Sending hugs to everyone xx I had my results back of Friday 20mm - Grade 3 - clear margin - clear nodes - no signs in blood. ER and PR positive and HR2 negative. I am not sure what stage this is though and have asked my BC nurse to confirm.   Currently undergoing physio for cording, the physio-terrorist managed to manipulate 4 of these to snapping point in first appointment. Now waiting for results of Oncotype DX.  Tissues have been sent to the USA to see if chemo is required or radiotherapy and tamoxifen for 10 years will do the job. This journey is definitely a waiting game, although I have every confidence that the NHS are giving me the best treatment available. Still feeling like everything is happening around me, and the pause button has been pressed. Sending love and hugs. Ange xxxx
Posts.Title: Results Back - now waiting for Oncotype DX

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady Fingers crossed for your results for the 13th (my birthday falls on the 13th so pretty good number really). I honestly don't know how I would have got this far without the support, strength and absolute respect for the ladies and gents on this site.  It kind of puts some perspective to this bloody awful journey we are all on.   Love and best wishes xxx
Posts.Title: Results Back - now waiting for Oncotype DX

Posts.Content: Don’t think I will be able to sleep a wink.  I have everything crossed for a positive outcome but that doesn’t stop my mind working overtime. Love and hugs x
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Thanks Leolady In the nicest possible way I am glad I am not the only one.  Appointment now next Thurs. I went to see the BC nurse anyway and they are keeping an eye on the swelling for Lymphodema. I also have referral to physio for the cording. Love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Thanks for the hugs I really do need them today.  I will definitely let you know how I get on Xxx  These groups are an absolute godsend when you need to share your thoughts without worrying your nearest and dearest xxx
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Hi Fishywishy It is horrible, my brain is just flicking through every scenario on loop!  The results absolutely determine our next steps. If mine are as hoped  radiotherapy for me if not a much longer journey. I am going in today to the appointment anyway to have my wounds checked as I have some ‘cording’ in my arm pit and a lump on forearm. I am hoping that the delay in results is just down to our overworked and underpaid amazing NHS. Sam thanks for the hug, hope you are getting on ok x Much love and let me know when you hear XX Ange
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, thanks for the kind words.  It is reassuring that this does happen (in an odd sort of way). Will need to be keeping all of my body parts crossed for another week xx Love and hugs Ange
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Morning all Not bad news/not good news - no news - just took a call from the breast care nurse to say my results are not back yet. My head is doing cartwheels now as it has been 18 days since op.  My consultant is on holiday this week so I was due to see another.  My mashed up head is saying they want my own consultant to deliver the message. Anyway it's going to be another week of torture. Has anybody else any experience of this please. Big hugs to everyone X Ange
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Hi Kim I think that is the normal waiting time 2-4,weeks after biopsy results.  It was the same wait for me and I had exactly the same thoughts as you, I just wanted it out asap.  I know it's really hard but you have to try and keep your brain occupied. Sending you a big hug  Ange xx
Posts.Title: Waiting time

Posts.Content: Hi, I was exactly the same as you scared and worried.  I need not have worried so much as everyone was absolutely fantastic. I walked down to theatre and the staff were chatting away as they got me ready, which took my mind of everything. When I came round I was so grateful for 'being back in the room' I couldn't stop thanking everyone. Good luck for tomorrow xxxx
Posts.Title: New and scared!

Posts.Content: Hi All Thank you for the reassurance of your posts,  i am coming up to two weeks post op, and have been feeling all of the above.and at times it feels like I have a swarm of baby bees under my arm too. Glad to know this is all part of the healing process. I think the one thing I wasn't really mentally prepared for was the sentinel node removal site being as sore (not desperately painful) but sore.  I seriously never gave this part of the op a second thought. Really glad to have access to everyone's thoughts and experiences. Back for results my results on Friday xx  Ange
Posts.Title: Pain after wide local excision

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief Thanks for sharing the link, really informative and positive program, which I would have missed without your post. Ange x
Posts.Title: BBC Scotland Beaston Cancer Centre - Episode One Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, I had the oncotype test back in March. It took around 3 weeks for my results - long wait - but well worth it, score came back as a 19 so no chemo. 15 + 5 radiotherapy. The outcome from a recent trial TaylorX has shown that a score of less than 25 does not require chemo. Fingers crossed for a low score. Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx Test

Posts.Content: Hi Tulip Looks like things are moving for you two appointments in two weeks is positive in this waiting game.  No expert but I would suggest that the medical bit is just a generic term used. The first appointment should give you your surgery results and the second your treatment plan. Good luck with both xx hugs Ange
Posts.Title: Medical Oncology

Posts.Content: Hi Figkip Just a thought but what time are you taking them.  Not sure if it makes a difference but I have been taking mine at 18:30 just after tea and fortunately haven't noticed any nausea.  I am hoping to sleep through any side effects. I chose the time in case I forgot to take them, and ended up having a panic all day at work. I am on day 12. I remember ginger was good for nausea, so maybe get some ginger tablets from the chemist, but you may need to check this out with BC nurse. Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & nausea?

Posts.Content: Hi, good to seeing your getting it checked out and really the experts will be the ones who can let you know for sure.   In many cases these turn out to be be innocent. When I found my lump more than half of my friends and colleagues said that they had had a scare, which led to nothing.  Fortunately I made the appointment to get it checked as mine wasn't as innocent as theirs. Mine was 12mm and did move about a bit, so close to the chest wall that I couldn't feel it lying down or standing up, only when leaning forward.   Two weeks post op now and waiting for full results. Fingers crossed for you, Love and hugs xx Ange
Posts.Title: Worrying breast lump

Posts.Content: Hi Julie I had the same symptoms, feeling in a dark place and tearful all the time.  A few weeks after starting tamoxifen it was like a black cloud over my head, After about a month I decided to split my tablets half morning and half tea time (this used to be how they were dispensed, cheaper for the one tablet) and the difference was incredible.  No dark thoughts, 99% less tears and improved energy levels. I am still a little more tired and a bit more achy, but hoping this will improve as my body adjusts, def manageable. I honestly believe I can live my life to the full on these.  I am on week 14 and 4 weeks out from rads. Rads were not too bad at all so try not to worry about them too much. My only advice would be moisturise plenty and often and drink lots of water. It is probably worth running it past your team before you start to split, hopefully they will not mind as there are a lot of ladies managing better this way, with the backing of their onc. Hopefully the same for you  Big hugs xxx Ange
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, Hope you managed to speak to someone about your tablets.  I hope you see some improvement the difference for me is significant.   Big hugs Ange
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & Low Moods

Posts.Content: You are very welcome Julie x There is so much going on at this point that you don’t know whether it’s the whole thing, the tamoxifen, the rads.  I can only speak from my own experience but 4 weeks out from rads and for the first time in 6 months I am starting to feel like me, which I never even thought was possible.  It really is a slow process but you will get there, there’s no rushing through x tears are a big part of this. A big huge thank you to you Leolady, in the early days it was you that managed to pull me through all the ****.  I am glad to see that you are nearly at the end of your treatments, and fab to see you have kept the positivity.  I remember oncotype-gate xxx Thanks for the sun advice too, my rads team advised to put cream on even under my clothes as some materials let the rays in.  I have found a fab cream on Amazon called Altruists.  It comes in a 50 and 30 has no odour and designed by dermatologists.  It’s cheap too £7 for 2 x 200ml.  Sorry would post link but on my phone, if do a search in Amazon it will come up with loads of other positive info.  The monthly rads page is an absolute godsend, it is lovely and supportive and makes you feel that you are not alone.  I even read through a couple of the previous months for any tips and what to expect - I’m a bit of a planner Hugs xx Ange
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Hi Julie Fingers crossed that the nighttime tablet works for you. That cream is fab, I’ve been using it for a month or two now, no reaction on the rad site. The whole family have been using it too - cheeky buggers! Saw my GP today and asked if he’d order the 10mg tablets, he said they were special order and really expensive compared to the 20mg which are mass produced - he said just carry on splitting.   Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & Low Moods

Posts.Content: So happy to hear this Julie, always lovely to see a light at the end of the tunnel. We are all going to be taking these tablets for a very long time so anything that makes things easier is always worth a try. I am nearly four months in and things are much better, I think our bodies need to make adjustments. A positive outlook always helps too, which in the circumstances is sometimes the most difficult bit. I am friends with Jill and another lovely lady Jan who I met on this site, and we absolutely can have a moan and pull each other back up which I think has helped tremendously. Hugs Ange xxx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Hi, I used baby sensitive wash and baby shampoo through rads, less chemicals, smelt like a baby, not expensive and did the job. ange xx
Posts.Title: Shower gel and body lotion

Posts.Content: Hi Dizzy The waiting is the worse time ever, what you don't know your head makes up.  Whatever happens tomorrow try and stay positive as BC is treatable and you will get through it. (Nearly the same as you 20mm lobular) Hugs Ange xx
Posts.Title: After operation

Posts.Content: Hi Dizzy Sounds like you are doing really well after only 12 days. Hopefully what you are feeling is just everything settling now, under the scar I did have some hardness but I think,this was just scar tissue and has almost gone now (5th Feb for my op).  Same with the swelling. Always best to check with BC nurse or consultant to put your mind at rest. Best wishes and hugs for tomorrow.  Ange xx
